how is the economy.explanation: Jobs come first: Nonfarm payrolls show total employment and job creation, unemployment rate indicates labor market slack, and CPI inflation (year-over-year) reveals price stability. Jobs are the most tangible measure of economic health for most Americans—when employers are hiring, the economy is working.

how is the economy doing.explanation: Jobs come first: Nonfarm payrolls show total employment and hiring trends, unemployment rate indicates how many Americans are looking for work, and CPI inflation reveals price pressures. Employment is the most direct measure of economic health that affects everyday life.

economic overview.explanation: Jobs come first in any economic overview: Nonfarm payrolls show total employment and hiring momentum, unemployment rate indicates labor market slack, and CPI inflation reveals price pressures. These three metrics capture employment health and inflation—the two things that matter most to everyday Americans.

state of the economy.explanation: Jobs are the best measure of economic state: Nonfarm payrolls show how many Americans have jobs and whether employers are hiring, unemployment rate reveals how many are looking for work, and CPI inflation indicates price stability. Employment is the most tangible indicator of economic health.

is the economy good.explanation: To assess whether the economy is 'good,' jobs matter most: Strong payroll growth, low unemployment, and controlled inflation signal a healthy economy. Nonfarm payrolls show hiring trends, unemployment rate reveals job availability, and CPI inflation indicates whether prices are stable.

is the economy bad.explanation: Jobs are the clearest signal of economic trouble: Falling payrolls, rising unemployment, and extreme inflation indicate problems. Nonfarm payrolls show whether employers are hiring or laying off, unemployment rate reveals job market weakness, and CPI inflation indicates price pressures hurting purchasing power.

economy today.explanation: Jobs come first: Nonfarm payrolls show total employment and recent hiring trends, unemployment rate reveals how many Americans are seeking work, and CPI inflation indicates price pressures. Employment is the most tangible daily measure of economic health.

current economic conditions.explanation: Jobs are the foundation of current conditions: Nonfarm payrolls show total employment and hiring momentum, unemployment rate indicates labor market slack, and CPI inflation reveals price stability. These three capture what matters most to American workers and families.

economic health.explanation: Jobs are the best barometer of economic health: Nonfarm payrolls show whether employers are hiring, unemployment rate reveals labor market slack, and inflation indicates price stability. A healthy economy means strong job growth, low unemployment, and stable prices.

how's the economy.explanation: Jobs come first: Nonfarm payrolls show total employment and hiring trends, unemployment rate reveals job market health, and CPI inflation indicates price pressures. Employment is the most direct answer to 'how's the economy'—if people have jobs, the economy is working.

economy 2024.explanation: Jobs tell the 2024 story: Nonfarm payrolls show employment trends and hiring momentum, unemployment rate reveals labor market health, and CPI inflation indicates price pressures. Employment growth has been the defining economic narrative.

economy 2025.explanation: Jobs are the key to 2025: Nonfarm payrolls show total employment and hiring trends, unemployment rate reveals labor market slack, and CPI inflation indicates price stability. The jobs picture will define whether the economy stays strong heading into 2025.

us economy.explanation: Jobs come first for the US economy: Nonfarm payrolls show total employment and hiring momentum, unemployment rate reveals how many Americans are seeking work, and CPI inflation indicates price pressures. Employment is the most direct measure of economic health.

american economy.explanation: Jobs define the American economy: Nonfarm payrolls show total employment, unemployment rate reveals labor market health, and CPI inflation indicates price stability. For American workers and families, jobs are what matter most.

economic outlook.explanation: For economic outlook, I'm showing the Leading Economic Index (USSLIND) which is specifically designed to forecast future economic conditions, combined with current Real GDP growth and unemployment rate. The LEI aggregates 10 forward-looking indicators to predict economic direction 3-6 months ahead, while current growth and employment trends provide context for where we stand now relative to the projected path.

economic forecast.explanation: For economic forecasting, I'm showing the Leading Economic Index (USSLIND) which is designed to predict turning points in the business cycle 6-9 months ahead, current GDP growth to establish the baseline trajectory, and CPI inflation year-over-year to assess price pressures. The LEI combines 10 forward-looking indicators and is the gold standard for economic forecasting used by the Conference Board and federal agencies.

is there a recession.explanation: To assess recession risk, I'm showing the three key indicators: Real GDP growth rate (negative growth = recession), the yield curve spread (inversion warns of recession ahead), and unemployment rate (rises sharply during recessions). These give us the clearest picture of current economic conditions and recession probability.

are we in a recession.explanation: To determine if we're in a recession, I'm showing you the three key indicators: Real GDP growth rate (negative growth over consecutive quarters indicates recession), the yield curve spread (inversions historically precede recessions), and unemployment rate (recessions typically involve rising unemployment). These three together provide the clearest picture of whether the economy is currently in recession.

recession risk.explanation: Leading Economic Index (USSLIND) predicts turning points 6-9 months ahead - consecutive declines signal recession. Yield curve (T10Y2Y) inversion has preceded every recession since 1970. Initial claims (ICSA) show real-time layoffs - spikes signal trouble. Sahm Rule (SAHMREALTIME) triggers when unemployment rises enough to indicate recession has likely begun.

recession indicators.explanation: The three most reliable recession indicators: Real GDP growth shows if the economy is contracting, the yield curve spread (10Y-2Y) warns of future recessions when inverted (negative), and the Sahm Rule provides real-time recession detection based on unemployment patterns. Together they give you current conditions, forward warning signals, and systematic recession identification.

recession probability.explanation: To assess recession probability, I'm showing the three most reliable indicators: Real GDP growth rate (negative growth signals recession), the yield curve spread (inversions historically precede recessions by 6-18 months), and the Sahm Rule indicator (triggers when unemployment rises sufficiently above recent lows, indicating recession has likely begun).

soft landing.explanation: A 'soft landing' means the Fed slows inflation without causing job losses. Jobs are the key evidence: Nonfarm payrolls show whether employers are still hiring, unemployment remaining low means no major layoffs, and inflation declining toward target. The jobs picture defines whether we're achieving a soft landing.

hard landing.explanation: A 'hard landing' refers to a scenario where efforts to control inflation result in a sharp economic downturn. These three indicators capture the key elements: GDP growth shows if the economy is contracting sharply, unemployment reveals if job losses are mounting (the painful part of a hard landing), and the yield curve spread indicates recession risk from monetary tightening. If we see negative GDP growth, rising unemployment, and yield curve inversion, that suggests a hard landing scenario.

economic conditions.explanation: Jobs define economic conditions: Nonfarm payrolls show total employment and hiring trends, unemployment rate indicates labor market slack, and CPI inflation reveals price pressures. Employment is the most tangible indicator of economic conditions for American workers.

macroeconomic conditions.explanation: Jobs are central to macroeconomic conditions: Nonfarm payrolls show employment levels and hiring momentum, unemployment rate indicates labor market health, and CPI inflation reveals price stability. These capture the employment and inflation picture that defines the macro environment.

overall economy.explanation: Jobs come first for the overall economy: Nonfarm payrolls show total employment, unemployment rate reveals labor market health, and CPI inflation indicates price stability. Employment is the most direct measure of whether the economy is working for Americans.

big picture economy.explanation: Jobs are the big picture: Nonfarm payrolls show total employment and hiring trends, unemployment rate reveals labor market slack, and CPI inflation indicates price pressures. For most Americans, jobs and prices are what define the economy.

economy summary.explanation: Jobs lead the economy summary: Nonfarm payrolls show employment and hiring, unemployment rate indicates labor market health, and CPI inflation reveals price stability. These three capture what matters most—jobs and inflation.

economic dashboard.explanation: Jobs top the economic dashboard: Nonfarm payrolls show employment levels and hiring momentum, unemployment rate indicates labor market slack, and CPI inflation reveals price pressures. Employment is the most watched indicator of economic health.

key economic indicators.explanation: Jobs are the key indicator: Nonfarm payrolls show total employment and hiring trends, unemployment rate reveals labor market health, and CPI inflation indicates price stability. Employment is what every economist looks at first.

main economic indicators.explanation: Jobs are the main indicator: Nonfarm payrolls show employment levels and hiring momentum, unemployment rate indicates labor market slack, and CPI inflation reveals price pressures. Employment and inflation are what policymakers, businesses, and markets watch most.

economy at a glance.explanation: Jobs at a glance: Nonfarm payrolls show total employment, unemployment rate reveals labor market slack, and CPI inflation indicates price pressures. Employment is the first thing any economic briefing covers.

economic snapshot.explanation: Jobs lead the economic snapshot: Nonfarm payrolls show employment and hiring momentum, unemployment rate reveals labor market health, and CPI inflation indicates price stability. Employment is the most direct measure of economic health.

economy check.explanation: Jobs are the economy check: Nonfarm payrolls show total employment and hiring trends, unemployment rate reveals labor market slack, and CPI inflation indicates price pressures. If jobs are strong, the economy is working.

economic status.explanation: Jobs define economic status: Nonfarm payrolls show employment levels, unemployment rate indicates labor market health, and CPI inflation reveals price pressures. Employment is the clearest signal of where the economy stands.

small business optimism.explanation: Note: The NFIB Small Business Optimism Index is not available in FRED. As proxies, we show: Consumer Sentiment (UMCSENT) which correlates with business confidence, Unemployment Rate which affects hiring decisions, and Retail Sales growth which reflects consumer demand that small businesses depend on. For the actual NFIB index, visit nfib.com directly.

business confidence.explanation: Business confidence indicators: Consumer Sentiment (UMCSENT) reflects overall economic optimism, Industrial Production growth (INDPRO YoY) shows manufacturing activity that businesses respond to, and Unemployment Rate indicates labor market conditions affecting hiring plans. Note: The NFIB Small Business Optimism Index is not available in FRED.

small business.explanation: Key indicators affecting small businesses: Consumer Sentiment shows demand outlook, Retail Sales growth indicates consumer spending that drives small business revenue, and Unemployment Rate reflects labor market conditions. Note: The NFIB Small Business Optimism Index is not directly available in FRED - visit nfib.com for that specific survey.
